prefix: Approach the following question the way someone in elementary school would.
solution: Since the ant starts at the top vertex, his next destination, vertex A, is equally likely to be any of the 4 vertices along the middle ring. Each of these vertices is adjacent to 4 other vertices, and since they are in the middle, exactly 1 of those 4 vertices is the bottom vertex. So, regardless of which intermediate vertex he goes to, the ant will end up at the bottom vertex with $\boxed{\frac{1}{4}}$ probability, by the symmetry of the 4 intermediate stages.
gpt_response:
To find the probability that vertex B will be the bottom vertex, we need to first see how many total ways the ant can walk to a vertex from vertex A. 

From vertex A, the ant has four neighboring vertices to choose from, so there are 4 ways. 

Out of these 4 ways, only one way leads to the bottom vertex. 

Therefore, the probability that vertex B will be the bottom vertex is 1 out of 4, which can be expressed as the fraction 1/4.
